Here is a guide for people who don't know how to calculate temperature by using the unit of Degrees Celcius/Centigrade (°C)

Degrees Celcius/Centigrade (°C) to Degrees Fahrenheit (°F) Conversion:

The basic formula to this conversion is by multiplying (x) the number that's in Degrees Celcius/Centigrade (°C) by 1.8 (9/5), then adding 32, and the result is the number that's in Degrees Fahrenheit (°F)

e.g. 18°C x 1.8 (9/5) = 32.4 + 32 = 64.4°F

So here are the precise conversion numbers (From 0 Degrees Celcius/Centigrade (°C) to 50 Degrees Celcius/Centigrade (°C)

0°C = 32°F
1°C = 33.8°F
2°C = 35.6°F
3°C = 37.4°F
4°C = 39.2°F
5°C = 41°F
6°C = 42.6°F
7°C = 44.6°F
8°C = 46.4°F
9°C = 48.2F
10°C = 50°F
11°C = 51.8°F
12°C = 53.6°F
13°C = 55.4°F
14°C = 57.2°F
15°C = 59°F
16°C = 60.8°F
17°C = 62.6°F
18°C = 64.4°F
19°C = 66.2°F
20°C = 68°F
21°C = 69.8°F
22°C = 71.6°F
23°C = 73.4°F
24°C = 75.2°F
25°C = 77°F
26°C = 78.8°F
27°C = 80.6°F
28°C = 82.4°F
29°C = 84.2°F
30°C = 86°F
31°C = 87.8°F
32°C = 89.6°F
33°C = 91.4°F
34°C = 93.2°F
35°C = 95°F
36°C = 96.8°F
37°C = 98.6°F
38°C = 100.4°F
39°C = 102.2°F
40°C = 104°F
41°C = 105.8°F
42°C = 107.6°F
43°C = 109.4°F
44°C = 111.2°F
45°C = 113°F
46°C = 114.8°F
47°C = 116.6°F
48°C = 118.4°F
49°C = 120.2°F
50°C = 122°F

And to do the opposite, you have to subract (-) the number that's in Degrees Fahrenheit (°F) by 32, then divide (÷) by 1.8

e.g. 67°F - 32 = 35 ÷ 1.8 (9/5) = 19.4°C

I hope this was helpful for you guys that didn't know the conversion of Degrees Celcius/Centigrade (°C) and Degrees Fahrenheit (°F)!

The part about 50% humidity at 30 or 35C puzzles me. But I don't see how this makes it feel hotter. Remember that "feeling hot" is related to how efficiently we can evaporate our sweat. At 35C there is more water in the air already, yes, BUT there is also "room" for more. In relative terms, the ease with which me can evaporate sweat (and thus, the heat we feel) might even be greater. A half-loaded ox can carry our luggage easier than a half-loaded dog.

For those of you who don't know the conversion, an easy way to estimate is to remember these three rough equivalents. 0 = 32, 100 = 212 and 16 is 60. You may also want to remember 37 is around 98 in case you are traveling, but you don't really need to. After a little trial and error, it can become quite intuitive. Using this, know that 30 is about a third of the way between 16 and 100, so it would be about a third of the way between 60 and 212. Roughly speaking, the temperature would be somewhere in the mid 80's. 35 is slightly hotter and Fahrenheit grows faster in scale so it would be the mid to low 90's.
For those who want more precise temperatures:
30=86; 35=95; 18=64; 23=73

I will do a thing now I rarely do. And it's to post to SciShow that they missed out on a BIG part of the explanation. Which also made them make a mistake in the title.
Humidity does NOT ALWAYS make it feel hotter. Anyone living in a cold country like Canada or Norway will know this. When it's cold, And we're talking <0 cold, Humidity makes it feel colder. And yes, there is humidity in freezing cold air too.
So... Humidity doesn't just "make it harder to sweat". It carries a LOT more energy (heat) than dry air! Simple test and proof: boiling water vapor (like over a pot), and same (boiling) temperature air. One feels "very hot", the other causes second degree burns within seconds.
In cold climates, let's say Scandinavia, 8 C during a sunny dry day, is considered nice weather and people walk around in T shirts. 8 C with a slight touch of rain, fog, or just simply high humidity = winter jackets.
